job_description:
The Law Society of NSW is Australia's largest and most influential membership association for solicitors. We're not all lawyers, but we work together to support the legal profession and ensure a just society for all.
We are currently looking for an Accounts Receivable Officer to join our finance team on a permanent full-time basis starting in 2026.
About the role
The Accounts Receivable Officer will play a key role within a number of financial activities undertaken by the Law Society and the various other entities that it administers. A primary focus of this role will be in the area of Accounts Receivable and Revenue Accounting, involving customer invoicing, collections, revenue recognition, monitoring and reporting. You will also be involved in monthly and year end reporting, engaging with auditors, as well as assisting the Financial Controller and Finance Team with ad-hoc tasks.
What you'll be doing
Invoicing to customers and processing of sundry sales transactions.
Debtor collections - Follow up on outstanding and unpaid invoices.
General Ledger maintenance to ensure that it accurately reflects revenue transactions that have occurred during the month.
Maintain and update revenue recognition schedules and track against budget.
Monitoring and processing banking receipts/debtor payments.
Meeting with department heads on a regular basis to ensure revenue is up-to-date and address any outstanding items.
Provide clean debtor report and commentary on revenue variances against budget to Financial Controller on a monthly basis.
Maintain and update debtor records.
Efficiently and accurately input financial transactions in the accounting system.
Provide ongoing support to internal business units for their revenue and invoicing requirements.
Ensure an exceptional level of customer service when responding to queries.
Banking of cash and cheques.
Support the Finance Team in monthly and annual reporting requirements.
Respond to Audit Queries.
Assisting in process improvements and system enhancement initiatives.
About you
Certificate, diploma or bachelor’s degree in business, Commerce or a related field.
2-3 years relevant accounting experience.
Experience in a chartered or professional/financial services firm would be advantageous.
Strong computer software skills, including intermediate knowledge and use of Microsoft applications, such as Word, Excel, Outlook.
Experience in mid-tier to large accounting software, such as Mircrosoft Dynamics Business Central or Oracle JDEdwards.
Problem solving and analytical skills, including the ability to identify issues and suggest solutions.
Excellent written and verbal communication.
Technically adept with a strong attention to detail and accuracy.
Process and deadline driven, with sound ability to prioritise tasks in order of urgency.
A strong service mindset, with a focus on working and assisting both internal and external stakeholders.
Ability to communicate with various levels of the business.
A desire to continually improve and grow within the organisation.
To apply
The Law Society of New South Wales is committed to building and maintaining a respectful and inclusive workplace, appointing the best person for the role and supporting diversity.
Applications should contain a CV and cover letter that outlines your key experience and motivations for this role.

The Law Society of NSW is Australia's largest and most influential membership association for solicitors. We're not all lawyers, but we work together to support the legal profession and ensure a just society for all.
We are currently looking for a Senior Payroll Officer to join our HR team on a permanent part-time basis starting in 2026.
About the role
The Senior Payroll Officer takes responsibility for the accurate processing of the Law Society’s payroll and timely delivery of all payroll related tasks, reporting and projects while ensuring the integrity of all payroll processes.
What you'll be doing
Ensure accurate and timely processing of company payrolls on a fortnightly basis, including ensuring sufficient funds are available in the payroll bank account, accommodating for public holidays and periods of Senior Payroll Officer’s leave.
Maintain payroll information and the payroll system by directing the collection, calculation and entering of data and ensure archiving and filing of information is up to date.
Accurate and timely calculation, payment and reconciliation of termination payments, payroll tax, superannuation contributions, overtime, General Ledger salary and leave provision journals and Finance payroll reports.
Accurate and timely preparation and reconciliation of income statements, reports and ad hoc requests, as required and in line with internal and statutory requirements.
Single Touch Payroll reporting, pay cycle and year end reporting.
Provide timely and accurate resolutions of payroll related queries to staff and management and liaise with HR regarding staff and payroll enquiries including new hires, terminations, remuneration, parental leave and Law Society paid parental leave and Government paid parental leave payments, conditions of service and internal and external reporting responsibilities.
Proactively manage instances relating to leave by working with managers, team leaders, and if necessary, HR to resolve situations which may include staff applying for the wrong leave type, not supplying appropriate documentation or are approaching a leave deficit.
Ensure compliance with state, federal and local legislative requirements in addition to Law Society polices and enforce adherence to requirements and advising staff and management of these.
Take responsibility for completion of Workplace Gender Equality Agency (WGEA) reporting.
Work with Finance and external Auditors to contribute to the completion of the annual payroll audit.
Assist and manage as required the workers compensation administration, including liaison with insurer and fulfilling reporting requirements.
Maintain accurate records by managing the storing and electronic filing of medical certificates, emails from HR, staff and/or managers containing approvals or pertinent information.
Provide system training to all new staff, with specific training for managers and team leaders and manage system upgrades and enhancements as required or requested.
Manage relationships with payroll related vendors.
Undertake projects such as process improvements, standardisation of payroll systems and continually review, recommend and implement improvements/changes to the payroll operation as necessary.
Maintain staff and management confidence by protecting confidentiality and ensuring the integrity of payroll operations.
Ensure professional and technical knowledge is up to date and relevant.
Any other payroll related projects/tasks as directed by the Director, Human Resources and/or Chief Financial Officer.
About you
Appropriate postgraduate qualification with extensive demonstrated payroll management and processing experience.
Continuous improvement experience.
Demonstrated comprehensive knowledge of payroll systems (a working knowledge of Access Micropay is desirable).
Ability to keep up to date and interpret and understand Awards and relevant legislation (including but not limited to employment, workers' compensation, superannuation, payroll tax and parental leave legislative requirements as they relate to payroll).
Ability to understand and apply organisational policies and procedures as they relate to Payroll and associated HR matters.
Intermediate to advanced computer skills, including, e-mail and internet applications. and an excellent working knowledge of Excel.
Strong analytical and numeracy skills.
Proven ability to use clear, concise language in correspondence with a ‘customer focus’ approach.
Team player with warm, approachable style.
Meticulous attention to detail and ability to work to strict deadlines including the need to be flexible during payroll processing periods.
Ability to take ownership of the payroll function and make decisions accordingly.
Strong sense of discretion, particularly with respect to sensitive payroll data.
Ability to be proactive and responsive in unexpected circumstances.
Problem solving ability.
To apply
The Law Society of New South Wales is committed to building and maintaining a respectful and inclusive workplace, appointing the best person for the role and supporting diversity.
Applications should contain a CV and cover letter that outlines your key experience and motivations for this role.

job_title: Centre of Excellence: Young People & Disasters Project Communications Officer
company_name: YOUTH AFFAIRS COUNCIL OF VICTORIA INC
job_description:
Role:
Centre of Excellence: Young People & Disasters Project Communications Officer
Hours:
0.4-0.6 FTE, 15.2-22.8 hours per week, 2-3 days per week; flexible working hours between 7am and 7pm Monday to Friday
Remuneration:
$89,861.43 p.a pro-rated, classified under the SCHADS Award at Employment Level 4.1. (YACVic pays above award rates, with generous T&C.)
Status:
This is a fixed term contract, ending 30 June 2026
Location:
Based at the YACVic office in Naarm, Melbourne CBD. There will be some travel in Victoria. Working from home arrangements are supported and can be negotiated.
About Youth Affairs Council Victoria (YACVic)
Youth Affairs Council Victoria (YACVic) is the peak body and leading policy advocate on young people's issues in Victoria. Our vision is that the rights of young people in Victoria are respected, and they are active, visible and valued in their communities. For over 65 years, YACVic has advocated for the best interests of young people (aged 12-25 years) and the sector that works with them.
YACVic provides additional targeted advocacy and services through our key services, YACVic Rural and the Youth Disability Advocacy Service (YDAS). Youth Disability Advocacy Service (YDAS). YDAS is in the process of transitioning to independence in 2026.
YACVic Rural also coordinates and implements a range of discrete projects across regional and rural Victoria including in response to disasters.
Background to the Centre of Excellence: Young People & Disasters
Victoria University’s Youth and Community Research Group and YACVic are partnering to establish the
Centre of Excellence: Young People & Disasters
(Centre). The Centre brings together expertise around young people (12-25 years), youth participation and disasters.
The Centre acts as a clearing house and central resource hub for knowledge translation, commissioning, contributing to, and disseminating research with, and about young people’s engagement with disasters. A major project within the Centres work is developing a website which will act as the digital front door to the Centre, and act as a physical clearing house for our work.
About the role
This role sits within the YACVic Media & Communications team working to promote advocacy in the best interests of young people and youth workers. The Media & Communications team communicate directly with young people and the youth sector about issues they are facing and solutions to address them, grows a strong brand to raise the organisation’s profile, and ensure we are seen as the key source of knowledge and expertise on youth issues.
The Centre’s key audience are focused on emergency management organisations, young Victorians, academics and researchers, local and state governments and community organisations, with YACVic’s key audience directed at young Victorians, the Victorian Government and the Victorian youth sector more broadly.
The Project Communications Officer will work closely with website developers to ensure smooth assimilation of the digital resources and content into the website for The Centre.
This role will produce impactful media and communications for projects across metro, rural and regional Victoria. This position works in a fast-paced environment across several tasks simultaneously, with strong collaboration with The Centre and YACVIC's Advocacy team.
Employment conditions
YACVic promotes the safety, wellbeing and inclusion of all children and young people, particularly those facing additional marginalisation including people with a disability, those who are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander or those from refugee or migrant backgrounds. We take child protection very seriously. All employees are subject to screening and assessment against child safety standards, including rigorous background, identity and reference checks. The successful applicant will require a current Working with Children Check and a satisfactory National Police Check (costs reimbursed) and must agree to comply with YACVic’s Code of Conduct, Child Safe policy and procedures. To be eligible to apply for this position you must be an Australian or New Zealand citizen, permanent resident or hold a valid work permit or visa.
YACVic is an Equal Opportunity Employer. People with a disability, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people from culturally and/or linguistically diverse backgrounds, LGBTQIA+ people and people of all ages and faith backgrounds are encouraged to apply for this position. We are committed to promoting diversity and inclusion in our workplace.
Key Selection Criteria
Essential
1.     Demonstrated experience in developing and maintaining a website and producing digital content to engage audiences in social change and community engagement.
2.     Demonstrated copywriting and editing skills for a range of channels, for example: website copy, blog posts and case studies.
3.     Demonstrated ability to set up and facilitate groups of people/ key stakeholders with diverse backgrounds in an inclusive, accessible and safe manner.
4.     Demonstrated ability to produce resources that explain complex information in a manner that is easy to understand, accessible and inclusive.
5.     Ability to meaningfully develop and grow collaborative relationships with young people, supporting them to elevate their stories.
6.     Excellent time management skills, with demonstrated ability to manage competing priorities, including with internal and external stakeholders, and media.
7.      Ability to work independently and as part of a team with different stakeholders to develop a final product.
8.     Demonstrated understanding of appropriate behaviours when engaging with children and young people from diverse backgrounds, and commitment to the Code of Ethical Practice for the Victorian Youth Sector and the Victorian Child Safe Standards.
Desirable
9.     Experience in producing Plain and Easy English materials.
10.   Experience working alongside young people in co-design, participation, or story-sharing contexts.
11.     Experience working on a major project with a defined timeline - e.g., a major event, conference, or a big campaign.
12.   Experience with monitoring and evaluation, particularly data analytics collection and analysis.
Application Process
Please refer to the full position description pdf via our website before applying
-
https://www.yacvic.org.au/about-us/work-with-us/ or email ***********@yacvic.org.au for a copy.
Applications should be emailed to the Recruitment Team via ***********@yacvic.org.au with ‘Centre of Excellence: Young People & Disasters Project Communications Officer’ in the subject line and must include:
A brief cover letter
Your resume
Your responses to each
key selection criteria
point (listed above), in a separate document. Here is a handy guide to addressing a key selection criteria - https://www.careers.vic.gov.au/how-to-apply/how-to-apply-for-a-job
Only applications that follow the above process will be accepted and considered for interview.
Please let us know if you require support to complete an application or would like to submit an application in a different format.
Applications close on Monday, 12 January 2026 at 5:00pm
, with interviews likely to be held in the week commencing, 19 January 2026
If you have any questions about the role, please contact
Jessica Standish
(she/her), Centre of Excellence Project Coordinator *********@YACVic.org.au ph: 0499 440 ***

Operations Superintendent - Production
Greenbushes Lithium Operation
Residential Full Time Position
Lithium plays a critical role in the transition to clean energy, and Talison Lithium is the world's leading lithium minerals producer with the largest high-grade ore body supplying multiple and complex processing plants - join us and be a part of the transition.
Talison Lithium aims to maximise local employment where possible by recruiting people who live in and around our local communities of Greenbushes, Bridgetown, Donnybrook, Nannup, Boyup Brook and Manjimup.
About the Role
This role provides an opportunity to join a growing team in the South West of WA. Reporting to the Plant Manager you will be responsible for managing and developing the operations team associated with some of the extensive crushing and processing facilities. This is a permanent, full-time, residential position based at our Greenbushes Lithium Operation. You can work a 40hr week, comprised of 5 days on and 2 days off, with flexible work options available.
About the Plants
The Greenbushes site includes three crushing circuits, and five processing plants, including a newly constructed crushing and processing plant which are ready for commissioning.
Processing steps include high pressure grinding rolls, dense media circuit, flat bed classifiers, screens, cyclones, flotation circuits, filtration, thickeners, high and low intensity magnetic separators, spirals and wet tables. Experience in some or all of these processing steps will be highly regarded.
Responsibilities include:
Champion safe behaviours within organisation;
Provide and manage resources for production and shutdown operations activities;
Empower, encourage and develop a diverse operating team ;
Ensure production is maintained to specification, recovery and production rates;
Ensure management of risks, hazard identification and workplace inspections; and
Manage cost of production.
About the Candidate
To be successful in this role you will be able to demonstrate the following:
Previous experience in technical leadership role;
Embrace diversity;
Tertiary qualification in Metallurgy, Chemical Engineering or equivalent; or relevant trade; or operational leadership experience; and
Willingness to guide your team while supporting a positive team culture.
Some of the many benefits of working with Talison include:
be home every night with a family and lifestyle friendly roster;
flexible working environment;
income protection insurance;
life Insurance for company superannuation employees;
attractive parental leave policy;
salary sacrifice options for remote area housing, motor vehicles and superannuation; and
participation in site performance-based incentive scheme.
About Talison Lithium
Talison supports many of the community projects, groups and sporting events our employees are involved in. Our future is within, and as part of, the community.
The Greenbushes Lithium Operation is located in a unique residential setting, near the town of Greenbushes atop the picturesque Darling Scarp. Being involved in the broader community is integral to our core business values of safety, transparency and inclusiveness. We regularly carry out site tours for local school and community groups and promote education through Mine Open Days and community events.
Supporting a diverse workforce
Talison strongly encourages applications from candidates from diverse backgrounds with a wide range of work experience. Talison takes pride in its unique location and the excellent work/life balance offering that our employees enjoy. Talison recognises that we are strengthened by diversity and is committed to providing a work environment where everyone is treated fairly and with respect. We are an inclusive employer and we welcome applications from all genders, cultures and identities.

This portal is accessible via all Talison Advertisements on Seek / LinkedIn, and directly at jobs.talisonlithium.com
We look forward to receiving your application for this vacancy.

Appointment is subject to an AFP records check and UK security clearance.
Open to Australian citizens, partners/dependents of UK-based diplomatic staff currently posted in Australia, New Zealand, Canada, US, UK passport holders with local permit/right to work in Australia.
Specific considerations for consular roles:
You should be aware that consular work can involve difficult conversations with distressed individuals. Emotional intelligence and personal resilience are essential. You will be well supported by your line manager, your team and colleagues across the UK in Australia network. You will have access to quarterly wellbeing sessions with a wellbeing supervisor and other wellbeing support resources.
The successful applicant will be expected maintain absolute consular confidentiality and impartiality, keeping in line with the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) Consular Strategy, consular guidance and Customer Charter, business targets and local procedures.
Learning and development opportunities (and any specific training courses to be completed):
You will be joining an enthusiastic and supportive team that takes continuous learning and development seriously and that values a diverse range of skills and backgrounds. When you start the role, you’ll be supported to become familiar with consular policy, as well as the structures of the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) and the operation of the British Consulate-General in Melbourne and the UK in Australia Network.
Mandatory courses:
In your first year, you will be required to complete the following courses:
Online FCDO learning modules relating to processing Emergency Travel Documents, consular case management and crisis management
Consular Fundamentals Course (delivered virtually)
Developing Consular Expertise (face-to-face at FCDO HQ)
Further opportunities:
When you are settled in the role, you will be supported to seek out further opportunities (both formal and informal) to deepen your expertise of consular work, and to develop wider skilled tailored to your personal interests and development needs. Opportunities can also include attending regional conferences, joining skills courses and applying to volunteer for crisis training and deployment.
Working patterns
Location: This role must be based at the British Consulate-General in Melbourne.
Working hours: Our core office hours are 09:00-17:00 Monday-Friday. Due to the unplanned nature of some consular work, a flexible approach to working hours and patterns is essential.
Leave entitlements: Full-time staff benefit from an annual leave entitlement of 22 days per calendar year plus additional office closures for some UK public holidays.
Travel: Some travel may be required for regional activities, such as prison visits, providing resilience to other teams, and for training purposes. This may include interstate and/or overseas travel.
Flexible working: This role is suitable for some hybrid and/or flexible working patterns, subject to operational demands. The importance of in-person consular services, relationship building, learning and collaboration mean that this role is not suitable for exclusive remote working.
The salary on offer is not negotiable.
No accommodation or relocation expenses are payable in connection with this position. All candidates must be legally able to work and reside in the country of the vacancy with the correct visa/work permit status or demonstrate eligibility to obtain the relevant permit. Any costs related to obtaining or renewing permits and visas are the responsibility of the successful applicant.
We are committed to being an inclusive employer and building a culturally diverse workplace. We actively encourage applications from people from the widest possible diversity of backgrounds, cultures, and experiences. Our culture of inclusion is underpinned by our excellent staff networks which cover disability, faith and belief, gender equality, social mobility, age, race, LGBT+, and how to be an ally.
Advertised start date is provisional and subject to completion of reference and security checks.

The Law Society of NSW is Australia's largest and most influential membership association for solicitors. We're not all lawyers, but we work together to support the legal profession and ensure a just society for all.
We offer a range of services and initiatives designed to proactively enhance positive mental health and wellbeing of over 33,000 members and practitioners from across NSW.
We are currently looking for a full time permanent Wellbeing Officer to join our Membership & Engagement team, starting in 2026.
About the role
The Wellbeing Officer is responsible for assisting the Wellbeing Manager in the identification, development and implementation of those services and initiatives which support individual legal practitioners while also seeking to provide law practices with the appropriate resources and frameworks to improve wellbeing within their respective workplaces.
You will be able to offer critical insights to the development of these resources and assist in their coordination and implementation. This requires an existing base of relevant knowledge and an ability to continually develop your understanding of the challenges faced by solicitors and other professionals in their occupational and personal lives.
As a supporting member of the Insights & Engagement team, you will support the Wellbeing Manager in the development and delivery of strategic initiatives and programs designed to service and support specific members of the profession through the various stages of their legal career journeys, ensuring that all we do is underpinned by the need to ensure a thriving and successful legal profession in NSW.
This role is ideal for an experienced professional with developing specialised knowledge and skills in mental health, professional wellbeing, and/or law, who has a particular passion for personal and professional development.
What you'll be doing
Assist the Wellbeing Manager in developing, implementing, and monitoring wellbeing resources and interpersonal training programs tailored to the unique needs of legal professionals.
Coordination and practical involvement with the implementation of wellbeing resources, programs, and initiatives;
Collaboration on development of new training workshops and presentations;
Assisting with the conveyance of certain training seminars or programs, including intermittent training delivery;
Feedback gathering and data collation on relevant programs;
Liaison with internal and external stakeholders; and
Internal liaison and coordination with our internal Events, Continuing Professional Development, and Communications teams.
Demonstrate a willingness to assist in training and program delivery and day-to-day project coordination on an ongoing basis.
Monitor and remain knowledgeable on current industry research, trends, the output of similar organisations. This includes staying up-to-date with developments relevant to the legal profession with respect to organisational culture, interpersonal skills, professional psychosocial safety, and mental health and wellbeing, including areas that are unique to specific segments of the profession itself.
Provide active and reliable support to the Wellbeing Manager throughout the identification, development, and implementation of new initiatives and programs. This will include offering critical insights during planning processes, assisting the Wellbeing Manager with the day-to-day operational functions of new and existing resources, and collaborating with internal and external stakeholders to support the Wellbeing Manager in the determination of the needs of the Law Society and the broader profession with respect to mental health and wellbeing.
About you
Bachelor’s degree or equivalent in one of the following fields or similar: Law, Teaching, Consumer Science, Sociology, Nursing (Mental Health), Social Work, Human Resources, Communications, Political Science.
Previous professional or lived experience in research and development, marketing and design, organisational health and safety, customer service, event coordination, crisis management, childcare, or aged care is highly desirable.
Developing competency in public speaking or openness to develop this skill.
Ability to write clearly and succinctly and to communicate actively, clearly, and patiently.
Strong administrative skills, especially with respect to abilities in scheduling, writing and grammar, and organisation of written materials and visual resources.
Competency in technology and common office software (e.g. Microsoft Office Suite, Teams, Copilot, Asana, etc.).
Strong abilities in perspective-taking and conflict resolution
Skilled in critical analysis
Highly flexible, creative, and optimistic
Strong ability to identify sources of conflict and appreciate opposing views simultaneously
Detail-conscious with the ability to work under tight deadlines and tolerate periods of higher demand
High degree of professionalism, integrity and ethical conduct
Highly motivated, proactive, and adaptable
Reliable, punctual, and committed to delivering high-quality outcomes.

About Aurizon.

Aurizon is crucial to the Australian economy, connecting miners, primary producers and industry with international and domestic markets.
